statement.p:
Suppose that A is an m\times n matrix and that B=A^TA.
Explain why B is orthogonally diagonalizable.
Explain why \vvec\cdot(B\vvec) = \len{A\vvec}^2.
Suppose that \uvec is an eigenvector of B with associated eigenvalue \lambda and that \uvec has unit length. Explain why \lambda = \len{A\uvec}^2.
Explain why the eigenvalues of B are nonnegative.
If C is the covariance matrix associated to a demeaned dataset, explain why the eigenvalues of C are nonnegative.

li.p: Because B^T = (A^TA)^T = A^TA = B, the matrix B is symmetric and hence orthogonally diagonalizable.
In the same way, C=\frac1N AA^T so that \uvec\cdot(C\uvec) = \frac1N(A^T\uvec)\cdot(A^T\uvec) = \frac1N |A^T\uvec|^2. Therefore, \lambda = \frac1N|A^T\uvec|^2.

What is V_{\uvec_2}? What does this tell you about the demeaned data?

Determine whether the following statements are true or false and explain your thinking.
If A is an invertible, orthogonally diagonalizable matrix, then so is A^{-1}.
If \lambda=2+i is an eigenvalue of A, then A cannot be orthogonally diagonalizable.
If there is a basis for \real^m consisting of eigenvectors of A, then A is orthogonally diagonalizable.
If \uvec and \vvec are eigenvectors of a symmetric matrix associated to eigenvalues -2 and 3, then \uvec\cdot\vvec=0.
If A is a square matrix, then \uvec\cdot(A\vvec) = (A\uvec)\cdot\vvec.

li.p: True. If A=QDQ^T is invertible, then the eigenvalues are nonzero, which means that D is invertible. Therefore, A^{-1} = (Q^T)^{-1}D^{-1}Q^{-1} = QD^{-1}Q^T, which says that A^{-1} is orthogonally diagonalizable.
True. In this case, there cannot be a basis for \real^m consisting of eigenvalues of A so A is not diagonalizable.
False. This condition implies that A is diagonalizable, but it may not be orthogonally diagonalizable.
True. The eigenvectors of a symmetric matrix associated to different eigenvalues are orthogonal.
False. This is only true if A is symmetric.

statement.p:
Suppose that A is a noninvertible, symmetric 3\times3 matrix having eigenvectors
\vvec_1 = \threevec2{-1}2,\hspace{24pt} \vvec_2 = \threevec141
and associated eigenvalues \lambda_1 = 20 and \lambda_2 = -4. Find matrices Q and D such that A = QDQ^T.

solution.p:
Since A is not invertible, the third eigenvalue must be zero: \lambda_3=0. Also, an eigenvector associated to \lambda_3 must be orthogonal to both \vvec_1 and \vvec_2. We can find such a vector by finding \nul(B^T) where B=\begin{bmatrix}\vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\end{bmatrix}. This leads to
D = \begin{bmatrix} 20 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -4 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 2/3 \amp 1/\sqrt{18} \amp -1/\sqrt{2} \\ -1/3 \amp 4/\sqrt{18} \amp 0 \\ 2/3 \amp 1/\sqrt{18} \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \\ \end{bmatrix}

statement.p:
Suppose that W is a plane in \real^3 and that P is the 3\times3 matrix that projects vectors orthogonally onto W.
Explain why P is orthogonally diagonalizable.
What are the eigenvalues of P?
Explain the relationship between the eigenvectors of P and the plane W.

li.p: If Q is a 3\times2 matrix whose columns are an orthonormal basis for W, then P=QQ^T. This means that P^T=(Q^T)^TQ^T = QQ^T = P so P is symmetric and hence orthogonally diagonalizable.
If \vvec is in W, then P\vvec=\vvec and if \vvec is in W^\perp, then P\vvec=0. This means that the eigenvalues of P are either 0 or 1.
